Komentar Darinke Pavlič Kamien: Iskanje dlake v napačnem jajcu
Kako je mesnina lahko domača, če se ne ve, ne od kod je niti od kdaj je meso, ki je v njej?
05 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Novice
V dobrem mesecu je meso že drugič napolnilo rubrike naših medijev. Pozornost v primerih, ko gre za hrano, je vedno na mestu, vendar bi bilo zaradi koristi potrošnikov te treba razjasniti ne samo z alarmantnimi naslovi, temveč tudi z dejansko razlago prekrška. Da bi ga preprosti ljudje razumeli.
Kako je mesnina lahko domača, če se ne ve, ne od kod je niti od kdaj je meso, ki je v njej?
Izjave direktorja Uprave za varno hrano namreč niso ravno plastične, kar zadeva vzroke za oporečnost in odpoklic avstrijskega mesa.Tako je še najbolj verjetno razumevanje razlage, da 18 živali med 9000 zaklanimi v sporni klavnici ni imelo opravljenih vseh pregledov in bi po praksi, ki jo izvajajo veterinarji, njihovo meso že zgolj zaradi tega moralo na uničenje. Torej gre lahko za povsem formalni razlog, čeprav s tem »spornim« mesom najverjetneje ni nič narobe.Podoben primer formalnega razsojanja je bila tudi najdba sulfitov v mesu, ki jih sicer ni dovoljeno dodajati, a niso strupeni. Njihova nevarnost je podobna tisti, ki ji bodo alergiki izpostavljeni v prihodnjih tednih v kakšni zidanici, če bodo nič hudega sluteč spili kak kozarec vina, ki ga je lastnik pred tem po tihem »popravil«.Pa temu ne dajemo posebnega pomena. Pri tem pa je javnosti povsem ušlo, da so se v to mesno zanko ujeli predvsem mali proizvajalci, med njimi tudi taki, ki na ves glas prisegajo na »domače«, in predvsem s tem privabljajo svoje kupce. Kako je mesnina lahko domača, če se ne ve, ne od kod je niti od kdaj je meso, ki je v njej? V teh primerih gre pač za grobo zavajanje, ki pa, sicer formalnim podrobnostim naklonjene Uprave za varno hrano ne moti toliko, da bi ukrepala.Pa je prav ta ohlapnost njihovega odnosa do porekla mesa zdesetkala slovensko prašičerejo, o kateri zdaj toliko govorimo. Če bi namesto golega formalizma ta organ v sestavi kmetijskega ministrstva zagotovil več reda pri doslednem navajanju resničnih podatkov, bi bilo takih afer manj, domača prašičereja pa bi živela v boljših časih. Tako pa zakotni tuji mesarji cvetijo, medtem ko slovenski veterinarski nadzor išče dlako v jajcu. V napačnem, seveda.

Darinka Pavlic Kamien's Comment: Finding Hair in the Wrong Egg
How can meat be homemade if one does not know where it is or when it comes from?
05 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Novice
For the second month in a row, meat has filled our media for the second time. Attention in food cases is always in place, but for the benefit of consumers, this should be clarified not only with alarming headlines but also with an actual explanation of the offense. For simple people to understand.
How can meat be homemade if one does not know where it is or when it comes from?
The statements made by the Director of the Food Safety Authority are not exactly plastic regarding the causes of the controversy and the recall of Austrian meat. Thus, the most likely understanding is the interpretation that 18 animals among the 9000 slaughtered in the slaughtered slaughterhouse had not undergone all the examinations and would follow the practice performed by veterinarians, their meat is merely for the sake of destruction. So it could be a purely formal reason, although this "controversial" meat is probably not wrong. A similar example of formal judgment was the finding of sulfites in meat, which may not be added but are not toxic. Their danger is similar to that to which the allergy sufferers will be exposed in the cottage in the coming weeks, if they unsuspectingly drink a glass of wine, which the owner has “quietly repaired” before. In doing so, however, it is quite common for the public to be caught in this meat loop, especially by small producers, including those who swear by "domestic", and in particular by attracting their customers. How can meat be homemade if one does not know where it is or when it comes from? In these cases, it is a gross misrepresentation, which, although the formal details of the favored Food Safety Authority, does not bother her to take much action. It is precisely this slackness of their attitude towards the origin of the meat that has decimated the Slovenian pig, which we are talking about so much now. If, instead of a mere formalism, this body within the Ministry of Agriculture provided more order in the consistent presentation of true data, there would be fewer such affair, and domestic pigs would live in better times. But so-called foreign butchers are flourishing, while Slovenian veterinary control is looking for hair in the egg. In the wrong, of course.
